captions.text:
North Korea is a bit of a black box, right?
It's got this rogue nuclear program. It's

under heavy international sanctions. There's
gulags. There's famines. The people appear

to worship this deified kid of a national
leader. To understand why that is, you really

have to go back to 1910 when Japan first colonized
Korea. And Japan at the time was its own super

crazy fascist imperial state, which Americans
know all about because we fought a war with

them. Japan wanted to convince Koreans that
they were a subset of the Japanese race and

to rally them to the imperial cause. And then
Japan collapsed, 1945, the North came under

Soviet occupation but the ideology stayed
there. So we think of North Korea as like

this last holdover of Soviet-style communism,
but actually it's the last holdover of Japanese

fascism. And you still see that today. North
Koreans are told that they are the purest

race on Earth and that their superiority means
that they need a strong leader to protect

them from the outside world and then they
have this leader who's kind of deified because

he's a holdover from the Japanese emperor
who was actually, you know, a quasi-religious

figure. So then in 1991 the Soviet Union collapses,
stopped giving North Korea all these subsidies,

and the North Korean government needed to
find a new way to keep its citizens' support

because they were so poor that they could
not feed their own people and 1 in 10 North

Koreans starved to death. So that's when Kim
Jong-Il, who was the leader at the time, came

up with the Songun policy, military first,
which is this big lie they tell the country

that they're constantly at this like low-boil
war with the entire outside world, especially

the American imperialist dogs, so you have
to give up everything towards the military

cause. It's really effective. Everybody buys
into it. There are studies that show that

even North Koreans who leave the country and
see how poor North Korea is, most of them

actually come back willingly. When Kim Jong-Il
died, there were millions of North Koreans

crying in the street, and even defectors say
that was more real than fake, which is kind

of amazing given that the country is really
poor and 1% of its population lives in prison camps.

And then one effect of this that works
really well in the North Korean government's

favor is that this militarism also distracts
the U.S. and the rest of the outside world,

so we're so worried about their nuclear program
and their crazy attacks on South Korea that

we actually don't bother that much with the
way they treat their own people,
who are the real victims of the North Korean system.

title: How North Korea got so crazy

comments.author: Sigmund Freud

comments.text:
+Sigmund Freud  I think what I took serious exception with was the wording 
of the original post. I'll use an analogous wording with a different topic.

"He talks about the 1% of North Koreans imprisoned in gulags, but 1% of 
Americans are in prison too. Our prisons aren't quite as bad as theirs what 
with the rampant starvation and torture, but we have long-term solitary 
confinement and horrible healthcare for our prisoners. Oppression isn't 
something only foreigners do."

I think that's like saying

"He talks about the 1% of North Korean women who have been raped, but 1% of 
American women have been hit on by annoying guys at bars too. Rapists 
aren't quite as bad as obnoxious douchebags, what with the extreme violence 
and mental anguish, but douchebaggery occurs in American men. Men 
mistreating women isn't something only foreigners do."

I'm obviously not downplaying rape in the USA, the wording was for 
comparison purposes only.
comments.author: Chris topher

comments.text:
+Sigmund Freud Yes that is my point, while are gov't is oppressive, it is 
not as bad as N.Korea. How could you argue differently? Yes innocent is 
subjective, but one can not argue that N.Korea's prison are on par or 
better to American prisons. My point is that American prisons while still 
oppressive (since Americans have used oppression as form of control since 
the birth of this country), they are not as bad as N.Korea's, which is the 
same point the OP was making.
comments.author: Dom Hudson

comments.text:
+Dominique Hudson Did you not read the original post at all? The op said 
that ours was not as bad as the North Korean prisons, but they are still 
oppressive. And innocent is really a subjective word. You may say they are 
innocent, but to North Korea they aren't. I may say that someone who smokes 
weed and then is imprisoned is innocent. He didn't hurt anyone or do 
anything to another person. But in the eyes of the state he is a criminal. 
In North Korea it is criminal to have differing political beliefs, to speak 
out against the government, to be related to anyone who does these things. 
The people in those prisons may not have done anything wrong but that 
doesn't make them innocent, legally speaking,

comments.text:
Drawings by a defector of life in a NK prison:

http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2014/02/19/eight-sketches-of-life-inside-north-koreas-prison-camps-that-will-haunt-you/
comments.author: Chris topher

comments.text:
That's a ridiculous false equivalency. Crime as we know it, by citizens, is 
virtually non-existent in North Korea. All the unbelievably diabolic shit 
we hear about that goes down in that country is perpetrated by the 
government. Hence, the prison population over there is made up almost 
exclusively of innocents: people who spoke out against the government, 
people not deemed 'loyal' enough, etc. And for these "crimes" they are 
subjected to possibly the worst prison conditions on the planet. Along 
forcibly working 15 hour days, every day, slowly starved to death and 
regularly beaten and tortured, pregnant women are tied to trees, have their 
fetuses cut out and left to die, prisoners are eaten alive by dogs, and two 
generations of your family that doesn't even EXIST yet can be condemned to 
your fate, just to teach a lesson.

Comparing that to solitary confinement (reserved for the worst actual 
criminals in this country: murderers, rapists, basically psychopaths) or 
simply pointing out the numbers we have here completely ignores the fact 
that, aside from drug charges, which I think are worthless, prisoners go in 
because they hurt somebody, in some way. That's their fucking fault. 
Comparing that to North Korea completely debases the magnitude of 
inhumanity that those insane fuckers have. Furthermore, prisoners get fed, 
have access to television, can smoke cigarettes, exercise, etc. etc. That's 
a paradise compared to a North Korean prison.
comments.author: Chris topher

comments.text:
+King Silicon Yes, I'm sure. We have 310 million people in the US, we have 
somewhere between 2-3 million prisoners.

comments.author: Chris topher

comments.text:
Lol. It's very, very obvious how either sheltered or naive you are.

The North Korean people aren't obese because they are constantly going 
through periods of starvation and live most of their lives in malnutrition. 

The average N. Korean child is much lighter and much shorter than their S. 
Korean brothers due to malnutrition  for example.

The reason they idolize their god king is because the government there has 
reached a point of control so masterfully it seems Orwellian to anyone with 
a proper education.

25% of Americans are not in prison, we have 25% of the worlds prison 
population, those are two very different things.

Mourning the loss of a leader and mourning the loss of a god are two very 
different things.

We do not look at our president as the sole governing power in the US, we 
have three branches with a system of checks and balances, as opposed to N. 
Korea which has a god king.

American executions of convicts is quite different from putting entire 
families into concentration camps.

 It's good to have some questions about other cultures and systems of 
government at your age, but having the benefit of search engines should 
make you think twice and do some research before you post shit like this.

not able to think beyond bullying each other with the propaganda they heard 
from different channels. Such profanity allows for oligarch dictatorship to 
order the professional  army and its resources to stay at its bases around 
the Ukraine while thousands of militants hired by the police ministry are 
somehow able to produce tv images of fighting with their bare hands against 
the full spec terrorists. The set of anti-constitutional laws been passed 
to emulate the state of war without the need to declare it. International 
aid money are still wasted trough the old corruption channels and covered 
up by the same old propaganda.
It's like watching the movie Matrix but with soviet oligarchs instead of 
machines :)

comments.text:
the original ENGLISH usage of angel meant just a normal messenger. So 
you're wrong there. The local variation continues to occur with new words, 
and great local fallacy you're using there. Your Ad hominems prove who is 
truly ignorant here. Usage is all that matters it doesn't matter what the 
"aryan master race usage" is.
comments.author: Alex At Six!

comments.text:
+Alex At Six! latin angelus is a messenger of god. Variation on the letters 
is not a changing of the meaning - it's nothing but a local variation based 
on the local speaking customs before the common education came into place 
in the past century. What you are describing as the majority is nothing but 
a ku klux klan of ignorant people and has nothing to do with lingual 
development
comments.author: Wily Werewolf

comments.text:
naaaaaah, It's just the fact that words meanings have ALWAYS been denoted 
by usage. Think of words that the english language has borrowed and made 
mean something totally different from their origin. Or even our own words. 
Angel once meant - Any messenger or hireling and now it means "a being from 
heaven" and Artificial once meant - Artful or skillful and now is a synonym 
for fake. It's just a matter of the times, and to fight the times is the 
truly ignorant thing. Society follows the whims of the majority no matter 
where you live.
comments.author: Alex At Six!

comments.text:
+Alex At Six! you can't have the ignorant majority and call it a humane

comments.author: Wily Werewolf

majority changes the meaning.
